questions.stem: According to Bordin's pantheoretical model of the working alliance, which of the following components refers to the mutual agreement between therapist and client on the targets or desired outcomes of therapy?

options.text: Tasks
Bond
Goals
Empathy

questions.explanation: Bordin's (1979) working alliance model comprises three interdependent components: Tasks (agreement on in-session activities), Goals (mutual agreement on the targets or outcomes of therapy), and Bond (the quality of the interpersonal attachment). Goals specifically refers to what the client and therapist hope to achieve through the therapy process. Empathy is not one of Bordin's alliance components, though it contributes to the bond.

questions.stem: Research on the therapeutic alliance consistently demonstrates that the strongest predictor of therapy outcome is:

options.text: The therapist's perception of the alliance quality
The client's perception of the alliance quality
An independent observer's rating of the alliance
The degree of agreement between therapist and client alliance ratings

questions.explanation: Research consistently demonstrates that the client's perception of the alliance is a stronger predictor of outcome than the therapist's perception or observer ratings. This finding holds across theoretical orientations and treatment modalities. The alliance accounts for approximately 5-8% of outcome variance, making it a modest but robust and reliable predictor. This underscores the importance of monitoring the alliance from the client's perspective using tools such as the Session Rating Scale (SRS) or the client version of the Working Alliance Inventory (WAI).

questions.stem: A psychologist terminated therapy with a client 18 months ago. The former client contacts the psychologist and expresses romantic interest. According to APA Ethical Standard 10.08, which of the following is the MOST accurate statement?

options.text: The psychologist may pursue the relationship because the therapy has ended and a reasonable amount of time has passed
The psychologist may pursue the relationship only after obtaining consultation from a colleague
The psychologist must not engage in sexual intimacies with the former client because the mandatory two-year minimum waiting period has not elapsed
The psychologist may pursue the relationship if the former client provides written consent

questions.explanation: APA Ethical Standard 10.08 establishes a mandatory two-year minimum waiting period after cessation or termination of therapy before a psychologist may engage in sexual intimacies with a former client. At 18 months, this period has not elapsed, making any sexual relationship an unambiguous ethical violation. Even after two years, the relationship is permissible only if the psychologist can demonstrate it is not exploitative, and the burden of proof rests entirely on the psychologist.

questions.stem: According to Norcross's APA Division 29 task force findings, which of the following relationship elements is classified as 'probably effective' rather than 'demonstrably effective'?

options.text: Empathy
Alliance
Collecting client feedback
Goal consensus and collaboration

questions.explanation: Norcross's task force classified relationship elements into three evidence levels. Demonstrably effective elements include alliance, empathy, goal consensus/collaboration, positive regard/affirmation, and congruence/genuineness. Probably effective elements include collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, and promoting treatment credibility. Promising elements include self-disclosure, immediacy, and emotional expression.

questions.stem: A therapist notices that a client has become increasingly passive and compliant in sessions, agreeing with all suggestions but showing little emotional engagement. According to alliance rupture research, this pattern is BEST described as which type of rupture?

options.text: Confrontation rupture
Withdrawal rupture
Negative transference
Therapeutic impasse

questions.explanation: Alliance ruptures are categorized as either withdrawal or confrontation. Withdrawal ruptures occur when the client disengages from the therapeutic process, becoming compliant but not genuinely invested -- as described in this scenario. Confrontation ruptures involve the client expressing dissatisfaction, hostility, or openly challenging the therapist. While negative transference and therapeutic impasse may co-occur, the specific pattern of passive compliance with disengagement is the hallmark of a withdrawal rupture.

questions.stem: Select ALL factors that research has identified as being associated with premature termination (client-initiated dropout) from psychotherapy.

options.text: Lower socioeconomic status
Weaker therapeutic alliance
Higher educational attainment
External locus of control
Younger age

questions.explanation: Research shows that approximately 20-50% of clients terminate prematurely. Factors associated with premature termination include lower socioeconomic status, minority status, younger age, external locus of control, and weaker therapeutic alliance. Higher educational attainment is generally associated with lower dropout rates, not higher. Addressing potential barriers to continuation early in treatment and monitoring the alliance can reduce premature termination rates.

questions.stem: According to Rogers and subsequent research, select ALL conditions that Rogers identified as necessary for therapeutic personality change.

options.text: Empathic understanding
Unconditional positive regard
Congruence or genuineness
Cognitive restructuring of maladaptive beliefs
Systematic desensitization of anxiety responses

questions.explanation: Carl Rogers identified empathy (empathic understanding), unconditional positive regard, and genuineness/congruence as the necessary and sufficient conditions for therapeutic change. While the 'sufficient' claim has been debated, these three conditions are consistently associated with positive outcomes across treatment modalities. Cognitive restructuring and systematic desensitization are specific techniques associated with CBT and behavioral therapy, respectively, not Rogerian conditions.

questions.stem: Select ALL elements that should be included as part of ethical termination of therapy according to APA Standard 10.10 and best practices.

options.text: Pretermination counseling with the client
Appropriate referrals when continued treatment is needed
Adequate notice to the client before termination
Immediate discharge without discussion if the client has not made progress
Documentation of the termination process

questions.explanation: Ethical termination requires providing pretermination counseling, appropriate referrals when continued treatment is needed, adequate notice to the client, discussion of the client's current needs and progress, and documentation of the termination process. Immediate discharge without discussion when a client has not progressed would constitute potential abandonment -- an ethical violation. Standard 10.10 specifies that psychologists terminate therapy when it becomes reasonably clear that the client no longer needs the service, is not benefiting, or is being harmed.

questions.stem: Select ALL criteria that distinguish a boundary violation from a boundary crossing in psychotherapy.

options.text: The departure from standard practice results in harm to the client
The departure involves exploitation of the client
The departure occurs as part of an evolving pattern toward exploitation
Any departure from customary practice, regardless of context or outcome
The departure compromises the integrity of the therapeutic relationship

questions.explanation: A boundary crossing is a departure from customary therapeutic practice that may or may not be harmful and may in fact be beneficial (e.g., attending a client's graduation, a brief hug at termination). A boundary violation involves harm, exploitation, compromise of the therapeutic relationship, or an evolving pattern toward exploitation. The key distinction is not whether a departure from standard practice occurred, but whether it resulted in harm, exploitation, or compromise of the therapeutic frame. Context, intent, and outcome all matter in making this determination.

questions.stem: A therapist is considering using self-disclosure with a client. Select ALL conditions under which research suggests therapist self-disclosure is MOST likely to be beneficial.

options.text: When it is infrequent and brief
When it is focused on normalizing the client's experience
When used to meet the therapist's own emotional needs
When it is relevant to the client's therapeutic issues
When it occurs frequently to establish a friendship-like relationship

questions.explanation: Research suggests that therapist self-disclosure is most beneficial when it is: infrequent and brief, focused on normalizing the client's experience or building the alliance, not used to meet the therapist's own emotional needs, and relevant to the client's therapeutic issues. Using self-disclosure to meet the therapist's needs or establishing a friendship-like dynamic would blur boundaries and potentially constitute a boundary violation. Different theoretical orientations view self-disclosure differently, with psychodynamic approaches traditionally minimizing it and humanistic/relational approaches viewing judicious self-disclosure more favorably.

questions.stem: Match each factor in Lambert's common factors model with its estimated contribution to therapy outcome variance.
questions.explanation: Lambert's common factors model estimates: Extratherapeutic factors (client variables, spontaneous remission, social support, life events) contribute approximately 40% -- the largest proportion. The therapeutic relationship (empathy, warmth, acceptance, alliance) accounts for approximately 30%. Expectancy/Placebo (hope, credibility of the treatment rationale) and specific techniques (interventions unique to each approach) each account for approximately 15%. These percentages highlight that relationship factors outweigh specific techniques.

questions.stem: Match each alliance-related concept with its correct definition or description.

columns.text: Client expresses dissatisfaction or hostility toward the therapist
The genuine, person-to-person connection comprising genuineness and realistic perceptions
Client disengages and becomes compliant but not emotionally invested
The therapy relationship provides opportunity to experience relational patterns differently than in the past

questions.explanation: Withdrawal ruptures involve client disengagement and passive compliance without genuine investment. Confrontation ruptures involve the client openly expressing dissatisfaction, anger, or challenging the therapist. Gelso's real relationship is distinguished from transference as the realistic, genuine person-to-person connection between therapist and client. Alexander's corrective emotional experience describes how therapy provides an opportunity for clients to experience relational patterns differently than in past relationships, which is central to psychodynamic and relational approaches.

questions.stem: For each APA ethical standard listed below, select ALL descriptions that correctly apply to it.

columns.text: Involves a mandatory minimum time period
Behavior is permissible under certain conditions
Must not be clinically contraindicated or exploitative

questions.explanation: Standard 10.05 (sexual intimacies with current clients) is an absolute prohibition -- no exceptions exist. Standard 10.08 (sexual intimacies with former clients) imposes a mandatory two-year minimum waiting period AND permits the relationship only if the psychologist can demonstrate it is not exploitative (conditional permissibility). Standard 3.05 (multiple relationships) allows them when they would not reasonably impair objectivity or risk exploitation. Standard 6.05 (bartering) permits bartering only when it is not clinically contraindicated and the arrangement is not exploitative.

questions.stem: For each evidence classification from Norcross's APA Division 29 task force, select ALL relationship elements that belong to that category.

columns.text: Repairing ruptures and collecting client feedback

questions.explanation: Norcross's task force findings classify: Demonstrably effective elements include alliance, empathy, goal consensus/collaboration, positive regard/affirmation, and congruence/genuineness. Probably effective elements include collecting client feedback, repairing alliance ruptures, managing countertransference, and promoting treatment credibility. Promising elements include self-disclosure, immediacy, and emotional expression. These classifications are based on meta-analytic evidence across multiple studies and treatment modalities.

questions.stem: According to Lambert's research, the therapeutic relationship accounts for approximately {{blank1}} of outcome variance, while specific techniques account for approximately {{blank2}}. The largest contributor to outcome is {{blank3}}, which accounts for approximately {{blank4}} of variance.

options.text: expectancy and placebo effects
extratherapeutic factors
therapeutic technique specificity
therapist competence level

questions.explanation: Lambert's common factors model estimates the therapeutic relationship contributes approximately 30%, specific techniques approximately 15%, expectancy/placebo approximately 15%, and extratherapeutic factors approximately 40% of outcome variance. Extratherapeutic factors (client variables, social support, spontaneous remission, life events) are the single largest contributor, underscoring that much of what determines therapy outcome lies outside the therapist's direct control.

questions.stem: In APA ethics, Standard {{blank1}} prohibits sexual intimacies with current therapy clients as an absolute prohibition. Standard {{blank2}} establishes a minimum {{blank3}} waiting period after termination before sexual intimacies with a former client may be considered, and the burden of demonstrating the relationship is not exploitative falls on the {{blank4}}.

options.text: one-year
two-year
three-year
five-year
former client
ethics committee
psychologist
licensing board

questions.explanation: Standard 10.05 is the absolute prohibition against sexual intimacies with current clients. Standard 10.08 establishes the two-year rule for former clients. The burden of proof rests entirely on the psychologist to demonstrate the relationship is not exploitative, considering factors such as time elapsed, nature and duration of therapy, circumstances of termination, the client's personal history, and current mental status. The two-year period is a mandatory minimum, not a safe harbor.

questions.stem: A therapist notices that over the past three sessions, a client who was previously engaged has become increasingly passive, agreeing with everything the therapist says but showing flat affect and arriving late to sessions. The therapist also notes feeling frustrated and bored during these sessions.

options.text: Client's avoidance of emotionally threatening therapeutic material
Disagreement about the tasks or goals of therapy not openly expressed
Successful completion of therapeutic goals and readiness for termination
Client's personality disorder diagnosis requiring medication adjustment
Alliance withdrawal rupture requiring therapeutic repair
Planned termination with appropriate pretermination counseling
Countertransference-driven therapeutic impasse requiring referral
Directly address the observed shift in the client's engagement in a non-judgmental manner
Explore possible disagreements about therapy tasks and goals
Terminate therapy immediately since the client is not benefiting
Increase the frequency of sessions to compensate for the client's disengagement

questions.explanation: The scenario describes a classic withdrawal rupture -- the client has disengaged, becoming passively compliant rather than genuinely invested. Contributing factors include avoidance of emotionally threatening material and unexpressed disagreement about therapy tasks or goals. The central concept is an alliance withdrawal rupture requiring repair. Appropriate responses include directly but non-judgmentally addressing the observed changes and exploring possible disagreements. Research shows that successful rupture repair is associated with improved outcomes and may itself be a mechanism of therapeutic change.

questions.stem: A psychologist in a small rural community discovers that the parent of their current therapy client is also the only pharmacist in town from whom the psychologist regularly obtains personal prescriptions. The psychologist notices increasing discomfort about the dual relationship and finds it affecting case conceptualization.

options.text: The unavoidable nature of multiple relationships in rural/small community settings
The potential for the dual relationship to impair clinical objectivity
Standard 10.05's prohibition against sexual contact with the client
The requirement to immediately terminate therapy with any client when a dual relationship exists
Managing an unavoidable multiple relationship per Standard 3.05 to minimize potential harm
A clear ethical violation requiring mandatory reporting to the licensing board
A bartering arrangement that violates Standard 6.05
Discuss the dual relationship openly in therapy and in supervision/consultation
Seek consultation on managing the potential effects on clinical objectivity
Refuse to fill any personal prescriptions at the pharmacy going forward to eliminate the dual role
Continue without acknowledgment since the dual relationship is with the parent, not the client

questions.explanation: Standard 3.05 recognizes that some multiple relationships are unavoidable, particularly in rural, military, and small community settings. The standard does not require termination but does require the psychologist to be mindful of potential effects on objectivity and to take steps to minimize harm. The central issue is managing an unavoidable multiple relationship. Best practices include discussing the situation openly, seeking consultation, and monitoring the effects on the therapeutic relationship. The Ethics Code prohibits multiple relationships only when they could reasonably impair objectivity, competence, or effectiveness, or risk exploitation.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding transference and countertransference in psychotherapy.
questions.passage: In psychotherapy, transference and countertransference are important therapeutic phenomena. [Transference involves the client's unconscious redirection of feelings from past relationships onto the therapist]. [Positive transference always indicates treatment progress and should never be examined therapeutically]. [Countertransference, when recognized and managed, can be a valuable source of clinical information about the client's interpersonal impact]. [Totalistic countertransference refers only to the therapist's neurotic reactions stemming from their own unresolved conflicts]. [Unmanaged countertransference can lead to boundary crossings, burnout, and therapeutic impasse]. [The primary means of managing countertransference include supervision, personal therapy, and ongoing self-reflection].

highlightableSegments.text: Transference involves the client's unconscious redirection of feelings from past relationships onto the therapist
Positive transference always indicates treatment progress and should never be examined therapeutically
Countertransference, when recognized and managed, can be a valuable source of clinical information about the client's interpersonal impact
Totalistic countertransference refers only to the therapist's neurotic reactions stemming from their own unresolved conflicts
Unmanaged countertransference can lead to boundary crossings, burnout, and therapeutic impasse
The primary means of managing countertransference include supervision, personal therapy, and ongoing self-reflection

questions.explanation: Segment 1 is correct: transference is the client's unconscious redirection of feelings from past relationships onto the therapist. Segment 2 is incorrect: positive transference (idealization, excessive admiration) may initially facilitate engagement but can impede treatment if unexamined. Segment 3 is correct: when managed, countertransference provides valuable clinical data. Segment 4 is incorrect: it describes classical countertransference, not totalistic. Totalistic countertransference (the contemporary view) refers to ALL of the therapist's emotional reactions to the client. Segments 5 and 6 are both correct.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the Dodo Bird verdict and its implications for psychotherapy research.
questions.passage: The Dodo Bird verdict is a significant finding in psychotherapy research. [The verdict, supported by meta-analyses by Luborsky, Wampold, and others, concludes that different psychotherapy approaches produce roughly equivalent outcomes]. [The name comes from the Dodo bird in Alice in Wonderland who declared 'Everybody has won, and all must have prizes']. [The Dodo Bird verdict has been universally accepted by all psychotherapy researchers with no opposition]. [The verdict supports the common factors perspective, suggesting that shared elements across therapies contribute more to outcomes than technique-specific factors]. [The Dodo Bird verdict proves that therapist training is unnecessary since all approaches work equally well]. [The finding has implications for training and supervision, suggesting the importance of relationship factors alongside specific techniques].

highlightableSegments.text: The verdict, supported by meta-analyses by Luborsky, Wampold, and others, concludes that different psychotherapy approaches produce roughly equivalent outcomes
The name comes from the Dodo bird in Alice in Wonderland who declared 'Everybody has won, and all must have prizes'
The Dodo Bird verdict has been universally accepted by all psychotherapy researchers with no opposition
The verdict supports the common factors perspective, suggesting that shared elements across therapies contribute more to outcomes than technique-specific factors
The Dodo Bird verdict proves that therapist training is unnecessary since all approaches work equally well
The finding has implications for training and supervision, suggesting the importance of relationship factors alongside specific techniques

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 2, 4, and 6 are accurate. The Dodo Bird verdict is supported by meta-analytic research and named after the Alice in Wonderland character. It supports the common factors perspective. Segment 3 is incorrect because the verdict is debated -- some researchers (particularly those studying specific treatments for specific disorders) have contested it. Segment 5 is incorrect because the equivalence of outcomes does not mean training is unnecessary; it suggests that relationship skills and common factors should be emphasized alongside specific techniques in training.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence for addressing an alliance rupture in therapy, from initial detection through successful repair.

items.text: Detect markers of alliance rupture (e.g., withdrawal, confrontation, decreased engagement)
Acknowledge the rupture non-defensively and invite the client to explore what happened
Explore the client's underlying needs, feelings, and expectations that contributed to the rupture
Validate the client's experience and take responsibility for any therapist contribution to the rupture
Renegotiate the alliance by addressing disagreements about tasks, goals, or bond
Monitor ongoing engagement and assess whether the repair has strengthened the working alliance

questions.explanation: The rupture-repair sequence begins with detecting markers of rupture (withdrawal or confrontation patterns). The therapist then non-defensively acknowledges the rupture and invites exploration. The next step is exploring the client's underlying experience, followed by validation and taking appropriate responsibility. Renegotiation of tasks, goals, or bond comes next. Finally, ongoing monitoring ensures the repair was successful. Research shows that this sequence, when completed successfully, predicts better outcomes than alliances that never rupture, as the repair process itself is therapeutic.

questions.stem: Arrange the following stages of planned therapy termination in the correct chronological sequence.

items.text: Collaboratively assess that therapeutic goals have been substantially met
Introduce and discuss the timeline for ending therapy
Review progress made during the course of treatment
Develop relapse prevention strategies and consolidate gains
Address the client's feelings about ending the therapeutic relationship
Provide referral information and plan for future needs if appropriate

questions.explanation: Planned termination follows a structured sequence: First, therapist and client collaboratively determine that goals have been met. Then the termination timeline is introduced. Progress review helps the client recognize their gains. Relapse prevention consolidates these gains. Processing feelings about ending acknowledges the significance of the therapeutic relationship. Finally, providing referrals and future planning ensures the client has resources if needed. This process should be gradual, not abrupt, and should be documented as part of ethical termination practice.

questions.stem: A psychotherapy researcher uses routine outcome monitoring (OQ-45) and the Session Rating Scale (SRS) to track a client's progress and alliance quality over the course of therapy. The following data represent session-by-session scores.
questions.question: What pattern do these data most likely represent?

options.text: Steady therapeutic improvement with no complications
An alliance rupture around Session 8 that was subsequently repaired, associated with a temporary symptom increase followed by continued improvement
Treatment failure requiring immediate termination and referral
A medication change at Session 8 that initially worsened symptoms before improving them

questions.explanation: The data show a general downward trend in OQ-45 scores (indicating symptom improvement) with a notable increase at Session 8 (symptom worsening). Simultaneously, the SRS alliance score drops sharply at Session 8, suggesting an alliance rupture. By Session 10, the alliance score rebounds above its pre-rupture level and symptoms resume their downward trajectory. This pattern is consistent with research showing that successfully repaired alliance ruptures are associated with better outcomes than alliances that never rupture. The temporary symptom increase during the rupture, followed by strong recovery, is characteristic of the rupture-repair sequence.

questions.stem: A training clinic compares premature termination rates across two conditions over five consecutive semesters. Condition A uses standard intake procedures, while Condition B implements role induction (pretreatment orientation) at intake. The following data represent the percentage of clients who drop out within the first four sessions.
questions.question: What conclusion is best supported by these data regarding the impact of role induction on premature termination?

options.text: Role induction has no meaningful effect on premature termination rates over time
Role induction is associated with a progressive reduction in premature termination rates while standard intake shows stable dropout rates
Standard intake procedures are more effective than role induction at reducing dropout
Both conditions show equivalent improvement in retention rates over time

questions.explanation: The data show that Condition A (standard intake) maintains a consistently high premature termination rate around 40-45% across all semesters. Condition B (role induction) begins at a similar rate but shows progressive improvement, dropping from 40% to 22%. This supports research showing that role induction -- preparing clients for therapy by explaining the process, roles, and expectations -- is associated with reduced premature termination and better alliance development. The progressive improvement may reflect both the direct effect of role induction on client expectations and the clinic's increasing proficiency at implementing the procedure.

questions.stem: Categorize each of the following therapist behaviors as a boundary crossing, a boundary violation, or an ethically appropriate action.

items.text: Attending a client's college graduation after discussing it in therapy
Engaging in a sexual relationship with a current therapy client
Providing pretermination counseling and referrals before ending therapy
Entering a business partnership with a current therapy client
Accepting a small handmade holiday card from a client
Discussing the dual relationship openly when an unavoidable community overlap arises

questions.explanation: Boundary crossings (potentially benign departures from standard practice) include attending a client's graduation and accepting a small handmade card -- both may be clinically appropriate depending on context. Boundary violations (harmful/exploitative departures) include sexual relationships with current clients (absolute prohibition under Standard 10.05) and business partnerships that create exploitative dual relationships. Ethically appropriate actions include pretermination counseling (required by Standard 10.10) and openly discussing unavoidable dual relationships (consistent with Standard 3.05 guidance for small community settings).

questions.stem: Categorize each therapeutic alliance measurement tool or outcome monitoring system into its correct category.

items.text: Working Alliance Inventory (WAI)
OQ-45 (Outcome Questionnaire)
Dodo Bird Verdict
Session Rating Scale (SRS)
PCOMS (Partners for Change Outcome Management System)
Corrective emotional experience

questions.explanation: Alliance measurement instruments include the WAI (based on Bordin's model, with client/therapist/observer versions) and the SRS (ultra-brief 4-item visual analog measure for session-by-session monitoring). Routine outcome monitoring systems include the OQ-45 (tracks client symptoms) and PCOMS (combines alliance measurement with outcome tracking for real-time feedback). The Dodo Bird Verdict is a research finding about treatment equivalence, and the corrective emotional experience is a therapeutic concept (Alexander) -- neither is a measurement instrument.
